title: Legacy Church seeks restraining order against New Mexico health secretary
summary:
Las Cruces Sun-NewsALBUQUERQUE — A church organization operating in Bernalillo and Santa Fe counties filed a federal complaint Saturday night seeking a temporary restraining order and a permanent injunction against Department of Health Secretary Kathy Kunkel and the state.
The complaint alleges that a revised public health order announced Saturday, extending a temporary ban on social gatherings of more than five people to church services, violates the First Amendment to the U.S. Constitution.
The church argued that since it planned to produce the livestream from an auditorium with a capacity of 2,500 people, it could do so in accordance with public health guidance on physical distancing.
Legacy argued that Saturday's amended order targeted houses of worship and violated the First Amendment freedoms of assembly and exercise of religion.
The federal complaint coincides with pushback from the state Republican Party and the National Rifle Association on some restrictions against businesses included in state health directives.

title: Unique physical, chemical properties of cicada wings
summary:
For example, many types of insect wings shed water, kill microbes, reflect light in unusual ways and are self-cleaning.
While researchers have dissected the physical characteristics that likely contribute to such traits, a new study reveals that the chemical compounds that coat cicada wings also contribute to their ability to repel water and kill microbes.
The researchers looked at the physical traits and chemical characteristics of the wings of two cicada species, Neotibicen pruinosus and Magicicada casinnii.
"And we also looked at the corresponding changes in the nanopillar structure."
The effort revealed that cicada wings are coated in a stew of hydrocarbons, fatty acids and oxygen-containing molecules like sterols, alcohols and esters.

title: Plastic bag bans reversed: States, cities, stores are suddenly banning reusable bags during coronavirus
summary:
Fearing the spread of the virus on reusable bags, lawmakers throughout the country have taken steps in recent weeks to usher plastic bags back into stores and ban reusable bags, at least temporarily.
In recent years, California, Connecticut, Delaware, Hawaii, Maine, New York, Oregon, and Vermont have taken steps to ban single-use plastic bags in one form or another.
Janet Mills has delayed the state's ban on single-use plastic bags from going into effect until Jan. 15, 2021.
Chris Sununu has directed all retailers to use single-use bags and prevented them from using reusable bags for now.
But politicians are concerned that reusable bags could bring in the coronavirus from home, while brand-new plastic bags may be less likely to carry the virus.

title: Flora Vista militia leader sentenced to nearly two years in federal prison
summary:
Farmington Daily TimesFARMINGTON — A Flora Vista man who identified himself as a leader of a group of armed volunteer border patrollers was sentenced to nearly two years in prison on a federal firearms conviction.
Hopkins plead guilty on Jan. 2 to being a felon in possession of a firearm and faced up to 10 years in a federal prison.
Hopkins' conviction stems from a November 2017 visit to his Flora Vista residence by two FBI agents, as he showed the agents at least nine weapons and ammunition.
Hopkins said in the plea agreement he possessed firearms including handguns, rifles and a shotgun along with ammunition for the weapons.
He also admitted to convictions including impersonation of a peace officer and failure to pay legal child support.

title: Latest New Mexico news, sports, business and entertainment at 9:20 p.m. MST
summary:
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (AP) — A University of New Mexico professor who was suspended for all of 2020 after the school found he violated sexual harassment policies is seeking a return to work.
The Albuquerque Journal reports Anderson School of Management associate professor Nick Flor last week filed a lawsuit to halt his yearlong suspension without pay.
The suspension also prohibits Flor from working elsewhere for more than 39 days during the suspension.
The lawsuit says the university violated Flor's due process rights during its investigation into a relationship between Flor and a graduate student.
Flor denied that he violated any policies, and his attorney said he wasn’t given a fair chance to defend himself.

title: Lawmakers, stakeholders react to Governor’s 2020 budget proposal
summary:
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (KRQE) – With the New Mexico Legislature set to reconvene in a few weeks for the 2020 legislative session, lawmakers and other stakeholders are reacting to the governor’s latest budget proposal.
A Democrat entering the second year of her first term, Governor Michelle Lujan Grisham unveiled her nearly $7.7 billion dollar budget proposal Monday.
One of the biggest parts of the governor’s spending proposal is a continuation of the so-called “moonshot” spending toward education.
Alongside raises, the education spending proposal outlines an overall $200 million dollar increase in K-12 spending, including more funds for at-risk students.
A Republican Senator on the Senate Finance Committee, Sen. Sander Rue says he too has questions about the governor’s proposal.

title: City of Albuquerque trash, recycling will not be collected on New Year’s Day
summary:
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (KRQE)- The City of Albuquerque’s Solid Waste Management Department reminds the public that they will not be collecting trash, large items, or recycling on New Year’s Day, Wednesday, January 1, 2020.
Residents who are serviced on Wednesday will be serviced on Thursday, January 2 while those serviced on Thursday will have their collection on Friday, January 3.
On New Year’s Day, all three convenience centers, Montessa Park, Don Reservoir, and Eagle Rock will be closed in addition to the Cerro Colorado Landfill.
The centers will reopen from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. on Thursday, January 2, 2020.
The landfill will reopen on Thursday, January 2, 2020, from 7 a.m. to 5 p.m.

title: Plastic bags are out starting January 1 in Albuquerque
summary:
The new law aims to improve the environment by curbing the distribution of single-use plastic bags.
Starting next year, single-use plastic bags that are used for carrying products from retailers will be banned.
This includes compostable bags and all plastic bags that are less than 2.25 mils thick.
Plastic bags cannot be recycled in residents’ blue receptacles but can be recycled in cardboard receptacles that can be found at many retailers.
The City of Albuquerque encourages residents to make the switch to reusable bags and some retailers will give rebates to customers who have reusable bags.

summary:
CEDAR CREST, NM (KRQE) – A mother and step-father are behind bars after being accused of abusing two of their children.
The couple was arrested Monday night in their East Mountain home after a five-month investigation found they allegedly abused and neglected their children.
According to the criminal complaint, the children were eating out of trash cans and were forced to stand outside in the cold without proper clothing.
Doctors also found the children were extremely malnourished, while Aaron’s biological child was at a healthy weight.
Daugherty said the children are in better shape now and are currently with a foster family.

title: APD: Intruder shot while attempting to enter home in southwest Albuquerque
summary:
Police crews are seen in a residential area in southwest Albuquerque on Thursday, January 30, 2020.
(KRQE Trevier Gonzalez)ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (KRQE) – Police are questioning a homeowner after he shot a man trying to break into his home.
It happened around 12:30 p.m. in the Westgate area near Sage and Snow Vista.
The Albuquerque Police Department says an intruder was shot while trying to get inside.
Police aren’t saying much, including if the intruder was a stranger or someone the homeowner knew.

title: City officials announce changes at pair of 7-Eleven nuisance properties
summary:
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (KRQE) – It’s been a long fight between the city of Albuquerque and two nuisance 7-Eleven locations known for their history of shootings, theft, and assault .
Today, the city announced both stores have agreed to comply with the city’s requests in hopes of clearing their nuisance label.
Last month, the city gave the stores 10 days to agree to make these changes.

title: ‘Lighten Up Albuquerque’ festival to project local art onto city landmarks
summary:
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (KRQE) – A new medium of art is coming to Albuquerque, inspired by festivals around the world.
Electric Playhouse, City of Albuquerque and Epson are partnering up to project art on city landmarks, using light.
The light projections will debut every Friday night from 7 p.m. to 9 p.m. at various spots around town until Feb. 1.
This is the first year for the ‘Lighten Up Albuquerque’ festival and Collins hopes it becomes a winter tradition for Albuquerque.

title: Award-winning photojournalist displays work in Albuquerque
summary:
RIO RANCHO, N.M. (KRQE) – He’s won countless awards for his compelling photographs.
Rick Kozak traveled the world for 30 years capturing history with his camera and now that work is on display in Albuquerque.
Now retired, Kozak now lives in Rio Rancho, and now at least a dozen of his favorite pictures are on display at Oasis Albuquerque on Menaul.
He says while he’s technically retired, he’s never really stopped taking pictures.
Kozak says he’s been privileged to experience history as it’s unfolding and share momentous occasions with the world.

title: Changes coming for ART routes in 2020
summary:
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (KRQE) – The city says more changes will likely come to ART lanes in 2020 after a dozen crashes in its first month.
The city is looking at different options for lane delineation for drivers along the main ART corridor on Central Avenue.
The Transit Department has decided to keep lanes near the aquarium blocked moving forward.
Director Danny Holcomb says the use of dividers during River of Lights kept that section of the route safer.

title: APD: 2 men charged in shooting across from Manzano High School
summary:
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (KRQE) – Police say it was a drug deal gone wrong that turned into a shooting across the street from Manzano High School on Monday.
Court documents say 19-year-old Brandon Gutierrez went to buy marijuana in the parking lot of an apartment complex across the street and planned to rob the dealer.
In his car with him were a friend, his girlfriend and her 2-year-old son.
However, the deal ended with the dealer chasing and crashing into them, and one of his passengers shooting at them.
An image taken across the street from Manzano High School shows a car with a broken headlight along with an APD Crime Scene Investigations vehicle.

title: BCSO announces outcomes of two Albuquerque operations
summary:
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (KRQE) – On Tuesday, the Bernalillo County Sheriff’s Office announced the results of two recent operations that took place in Albuquerque.

title: Legislature 2020: Lawmakers consider funding for New Mexico’s roads
summary:
SANTA FE, N.M. (KRQE) – State lawmakers are debating how to make sure New Mexico’s roads are safe and well maintained.
Last year, lawmakers spent hundreds of millions of dollars in new money on roads.

title: NEW MEXICO MEDICAL CANNABIS ENROLLMENT EXCEEDS COLORADO FOR FIRST TIME
summary:
Patient enrollment in New Mexico’s Medical Cannabis Program officially reached 82,147 patients, according to recent data released by the New Mexico Department of Health (NMDOH).
Enrollment in Colorado’s medical cannabis program reached 81,893 as of February 29, 2020.
Since legalization of the adult-use of cannabis in Colorado in 2014, the Colorado medical cannabis program has declined from a high of nearly 115,000 cardholders to less than 82,000 currently.
Meanwhile in Colorado, more than 286,000 plants were cultivated state wide for medical cannabis patient needs with an enrollment similar to New Mexico.
Ultra Health has been at the forefront of patient-rights issues and continues to fight for adequate supply and rural access in the New Mexico medical cannabis market.

title: Driver leads APD, NMSP officers on chase across town
summary:
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (KRQE) – New video shows a state police chase ending in Albuquerque with spike strips and a PIT maneuver.
Officers say they attempted to pull over Isaiah Aguilar for driving without a license plate back in February.
When the car finally stopped and Aguilar was in cuffs, he told police he borrowed the car for a hundred dollars.
Police say one passenger, Kayleigh Smith was also found with heroin and meth.
Court records show Aguilar and Smith have lengthy criminal histories including drug charges and car theft.

title: Police investigate fatal two-vehicle crash
summary:
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (KRQE) – The Albuquerque Police Department is continuing their investigation into a fatal crash.
It happened on Monday evening at Second Street and Constitution just north of downtown.
Police say the driver of a Nissan ran a stop sign and collided with an Infiniti in the intersection.
The driver of the Nissan, who was not wearing a seatbelt, was killed.
The other driver was not seriously hurt.

title: Saturday night’s sky to feature full “Snow” moon
summary:
The February full moon is known most commonly as the snow moon for the abundance of snow in mid-winter.
The problem comes in calculating 90% of perigee because apogee and perigee points change month to month.
If the 90% is calculated based on the year’s farthest apogee and closest perigee, February’s full moon does not count as a supermoon.
However, if it is calculated using this particular month’s closest and farthest point, the snow moon does come within 90% of the closest possible approach.
The February full moon will make the 4th closest approach to earth of the 13 full moons this year.

title: New Dinosaur Discovered in New Mexico Is One of the Last Known Surviving Raptors
summary:
A new feathered dinosaur that lived in New Mexico 67 million years ago is one of the last known surviving raptor species, according to a new publication in the journal Scientific Reports.
In 2008, Sullivan found fossils of the new species in Cretaceous rocks of the San Juan Basin, New Mexico.
Dineobellator, as well as its Asian cousin Velociraptor, belong to a group of dinosaurs known as the dromaeosaurids.
Jasinski plans to continue his field research in New Mexico with the hope of finding more fossils.
Robert Sullivan is a research associate at the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science in Albuquerque.

title: US gun industry groups urge lawmakers to keep gun shops open
summary:
Across the US, a patchwork of orders and local ordinances allowing gun stores to remain open as “essential businesses” has emerged as the coronavirus crisis has developed.
In Connecticut, Democratic senator and gun-control advocate Richard Blumenthal argued that closing gun stores would be broadly in line with other anti-coronavirus measures, including restrictions on travel and assembly.
“Plain and simple, there is no reason why gun stores should be given this exemption,” the senator tweeted.
In Pennsylvania, Governor Tom Wolf allowed gun shops to open on a limited basis, reversing an earlier order at the urging of several state supreme court justices.
The Los Angeles county sheriff’s department began closing gun shops on Tuesday, but dropped the effort less than 12 hours later.

title: VIDEO: KRQE News 13 Webcast 03/07/2020
summary:
RATON, N.M. (KRQE) – A Raton teen is helping people fighting COVID-19 in a big way.
After learning the hospital where his mom works were in desperate need of intubation boxes, he got to work and started building them himself.
For many people, it's not a simple task, but when 16-year-old Iyn Blacksten heard what the hospital needed where his mom is an ICU nurse, he says he knew with his skill set, he could easily take on the task.
"I told her that I could probably try and build these out of plexiglass and she said if I could do that and she said if I could get that done then I would so I tried to build one and whenever I brought it to the hospital that's when they asked me if I could start building some more for them," said Iyn.

Now based in Wisconsin, the legendary Dixon’s Apple Orchard is bringing a truckload of its famous apples to Albuquerque on Saturday, October 12.
“It is just incredible, the support, and the desire to have these apples,” said Becky Mullane, co-owner of Dixon’s Apple Orchard.
Over the years, hundreds of thousands of people bought apples from the farm, which became well-known for its champagne apples.
For the first time since moving to Wisconsin, the orchard is bringing a truckload of apples back to New Mexico.

title: ABQ Ride Luminaria Tour tickets go on sale November 29
summary:
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (KRQE) – On Friday, November 29, 2019, at 10 a.m. tickets for ABQ Ride’s 55th annual Luminaria Tour will go on sale online.
This annual Albuquerque Christmas Eve tradition takes guests through a 45-minute tour through the Old Town and Country Club area to experience the holiday season.
Those wishing to attend are encouraged to purchase tickets as soon as possible, as tickets sell out quickly.
Guests are asked to arrive at the Albuquerque Convention Center where the tour will begin no later than 20 minutes ahead of their scheduled departure time.
Free parking will be available at the Convention Center’s eastside parking structure located at Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Broadway.

title: 📸 Through The Lens | Downtown Shot
summary:

In our pre-COVID-19 world, the four days of the Kansas Relays would kick off today at Rock Chalk Park.
I grew from a young teenager to an aged sage watching and covering the Kansas Relays.
When the 1970 Kansas Relays began, I was there for the first time as a 19-year-old photographer working for the Topeka Capital-Journal.
In 2011, a new downtown shot put event was added thanks to cooperation between the Relays and the city of Lawrence.

title: 7 Must-Visit Sand Dunes In The Southwest
summary:
Regardless of the reason, sand dunes have always held a special fascination for me.
Colorado’s Great Sand Dunes National Park & Preserve gets about half a million visitors a year, and the United States National Park Service recently added New Mexico’s stunning White Sands to its roster of parks.
I have since learned that sand dunes exist all over the country, and I often make detours in my travels to take them in.
From my home in Arizona, I especially appreciate the sands of the Southwest -- those multicolored dunes that flourish in the desert and high-desert locales.
Here are seven must-visit sand dunes of the Southwest.

title: Pandemic Journal, March 30–April 5
summary:
On my last day with him, I lifted a small DV camera and made a fourteen-minute recording of our conversation.
This was, I knew, the final scene of my film on John, which I have been working on for years.
My mother suggests that my son, who is thirteen, keep a journal while he’s home and the virus rages.
Mosques across the country have, of late, initiated special prayers at night for protection against the present pandemic..
I just hope that whatever the eventual outcome of the pandemic, we can all find some joy amid the constraints that Covid-19 has placed on us.
